Great question! We currently dont see Ssa as necessary for any detectors/printers we want to build.

Imho slither should focus on implementing a reference resolver; until it has that its output can not be trusted...
it has reference resolution, but it's not an explicit API. there's an analysis step that builds a CFG. you can traverse the CFG in either direction to figure out what references what
No i mean resolving references to identical objects across compilation units. Let me spin up a repro repo.
Check this out https://github.com/hacker-DOM/reference-resolving
I'll just write it in the readme so we don't waste ppls' time
mmh what is the issue on this repo? Slither seems to be working fine
Just updated readme. Also raised issue where we can discuss this https://github.com/crytic/slither/issues/2102

Actually this is a misuse of the python API 😅
- First, there is two compilations units here, so two contracts named `A`. If you use `next()` over a python set, you will only see the first one
- Then within the context of `A` there is no reference to `a_main`, so reference is correctly empty. If you want to see the reference, you need to access the function `A.a_main()` that lives in the contract B or C.  

Functions and contracts are duplicate based on their inheritance usage, as it's needed for static analysis. Happy to continue this discussion on github to not add noise here. But we definitely have room for improvements in the documentation of slither's internals.

However saying slither cannot be trusted because you identify a potential bug sounds extreme tbh 🙂 (in particular if the bug is in your script 😅)
Err if slither doesn’t work: fix slither? Why another tool?
BTW, FYI if haven’t seen https://github.com/pessimistic-io/slitherin 👀️️

It sucks that slither is a bit of a sales funnel for ToB which makes sense why other security companies are considering making their own tool.

But us as users suffer because well we can’t be bothered with newer and newer tools. Just give slither (vyper wen?) and make that the standard maintained by everyone?
FWIW, there is also Pyrometer (early Beta, and see my issue 1 re Vyper) https://github.com/nascentxyz/pyrometer

imo motivation doesn't need to be only sales funnel for companies but rather to increase effectiveness during the audits since it is easier to work with your own tool and make it for your needs

also I think it is useful to have diversity in tooling so anyone can use what suits him best

this tool was primarily built as a testing framework that should be fast and provide typehinting and other things for best user experience. Detectors were just easy to add when you built LSP from scratch
https://medium.com/@exactly_protocol/exactly-protocol-incident-post-mortem-b4293d97e3ed

- slither doesn't have a testing framework

ExactlyProtocol (Optimisim) vulnerability: on line 764 of `permit` modifer, `safePermit` in the `address(token)` is invoked. But why debugger says `safePermit` in `DebtManager` is being called? Also the parameters are different..
safePermit is a library function I believe

Yes, it is a function inside SafeERC20Upgradeable library. I still can’t wrap my head around how safePermit inside DebtManager is invoked though. The code clearly says IERC20PermitUpgradeable(address(token)).safePermit(…)
Address(token) is  a injected fake token
Yes it is the fake token created by the attacker. But safePermit inside DebtManager(from the protocol) is called inside debugger.
if the library function is private, then it gets inlined into the contract

pls RT, we are currently investigating the issue

Great to see some audit firms in the replies shilling their services and saying that we should have had the bug fix audited, even though it literally says in the blog post that the bug fix was audited. Similar thing happened straight after the attack. Audit firms and others spreading misinformation because they can't be bothered to read or are too eager to shill.
name and shame. if you're an audit firm trying to shill your shit after an exploit, you're like that creep who comes after someone when they just had a breakup hoping to catch the rebound.
the early detection shillers are the worst offenders.
Agreed. There's even some that try to message you in the hours that follow to sell their products, as if you don't have other things to do.
it's one of the easiest ways to ensure nobody will work with you.
Do you mean detecting hacks by monitoring or minimizing their occurrence by starting security early (e.g. threat modeling)?
You got messages selling security products right after the exploit?
Quite "unfortunate" time.
strike rod while iron hot. some take it a bit too far.
i think that in the last cycle many new security service firms with web2 mentality (aggressive marketing is one of them, but also other characteristics) started to work in this space.

There is nothing wrong with web2 mentality. In fact, in my opinion, this is missing. There are plenty of ready-made structures, techniques and methodologies that have been developed over the years in traditional security and there is no need to reinvent the wheel. So let's not cancel it because of some bad marketing.

You think that threat modelling and threat detection is bad? Just for clarity. If performed correctly you realise this forms part of modern day responsible disclosure also. I appreciate not everyone has their motives correctly but I mean it’s not always a manipulation tactic.

I believe there might be an issue of mixing topics here. The exploit detection software (vs. comprehensive threat modelling) is simply bypassed by using a private mem pool or other transaction masking tricks.
Sure I agree but being late to the party isn’t always “bad” specifically as well. You can notify crafted attacks and perhaps help avoid total disaster at times.
Just to be clear I am not condoning throwing people/projects under the bus either.

Hello ERC-20. Because of broken design of approve(), and useless function increaseAllowance() this $24M phishing scam was possible.  I suggest any projects to look alternatives for ERC-20. https://vxtwitter.com/WuBlockchain/status/1699631887994806709
ERC-20 is the cancer of Ethereum security.
Is the reason they use `increaseAllowance` instead of `approve` just because Metamask doesn't show the special approval UI for `increaseAllowance`?
Note that increaseAllowance() is completely useless was was lobbied in by security researchers that wanted to make name for themselves and rake in more audit money. So this one is on you.
That's why I was wondering... increaseAllowance always seemed like a solution to a nonexistant problem, now it's being used for exploits 🤦‍♂️
You always love to trash ERC-20 yet I have never seen a better suggestion
This is so unproductive - what are projects supposed to do exactly? Not use the only token standard that everyone supports?
The developer and security community can look backwards to the bad historical decisions and get rid of them. Like increaseAllowance() as the baby step.
It's not projects fault, it's the Ethereum security community's fault. More critical thinking is needed to address these issues.
increaseAllowance isn't even part of the erc20 spec
Then it's good to flag it in the audits
Note that it was implemented because auditors demanded it
@miohtama - the approve issue: https://blog.smartdec.net/erc20-approve-issue-in-simple-words-a41aaf47bca6

I don't understand what the point you're trying to make here is. Like ok... some bad auditors forced a design through which, in retrospect, was bad. What's the point of pointing that out? It literally doesn't make a difference now?
Because the security auditors are the key group to prevent these kind of mistakes in the future
Make sure the future tokens are safer
rather than push for tokens, it's more realistic and feasible to push MetaMask do better in terms of security

just gonna point out that's definitely not the point you were making when you declared erc20 the "cancer of ethereum security" and pinned the blame of the phishing attack solely on "the broken design of approve()" and not, say, poor user education, bad wallet ux, etc etc etc :)
A little bit of trolling I made people to think at least
Because the usual response of the security auditors on "why should I care"
You should care because you are selling security

The solution is relatively simple. Contribute to standards like SCSVS or ETHTtrust and try to make them better. And during conferences such as the Defi Security Summit, raise issues that from your perspective are pain in the ass.

I think this will bring more attention than trolling 😉
Bad ux is the bigger issue imo
In general in this space

Bad UX is direct consequence of ERC-20 design. Because the underlying architecture is a mess, it is hard to design good UX. Other chains like e.g. Cosmos do not have this issue for its tokens, hinting that a better token design is something that addresses these issues.

Also blog.pessimistic.io/auditors-notes-erc20-integration-tips-3b150021b8c0?1 

Just fyi 🫡
Idk, I am on the edge of releasing something that makes all of this very readable and decent ux, despite the complicated underlying code. Pocket Universe and similar do this well as wallets.

Btw, I wrote an article about white hacks / gray hacks, where opinions are quite divided on whether "good intentions are enough". As a solution here, I propose to add a policy by the team, so that it is always the people responsible for the project who decide in advance.

I am curious about your opinion frens, constructive criticism and ways to improve this policy are welcome.

https://twitter.com/Composable_Sec/status/1699482901107065207?s=20
I think bad ux is direct consequence of nascency of industry.
Good ux will come on top of whatever is underlying and sort things over time.

Coders are rarely designers, and in somewhat disorganized open source development they rarely work together at the same time to put a product out at the beginning. It all gets figured out as time goes on. It's happened in OSS since the beginning of time.

While this is true as well, the core of the problem is that simple transfer of tokens should be obvious. It's a function that says transfer, takes output and takes amount. Even a non-coder should be able to read it. This is case for any other blockchain, so designs that are different and better than ERC-20 are possible. If the underlying function is simple, creating a good UX is easier and no user education is needed.

We do not, for example, need to educate users how to send money between bank accounts. Why would we need to educate them how to send tokens. It's the thinking that's broken here.
Saying "but cannot be nothing better" mean that you have one eye closed

This seems ideal of course. One issue though as you note is so few companies have any kind of bug bounty program. Also, many that do claim to have a bounty program don't pay or reply to messages (although they fix the issues).

With a team of 6 guys age 22-24 it's hard to convince them to spend the time and effort to get a proper program in place instead of spending their days buying lambos. But this is often who the teams are that get exploited.

This isn't my position, to be clear. Things are iterative.

Regarding bank accounts, contrarily I think we do need to educate users how to send money between them, and you see banks do this throughout the several steps it takes you to send cash. Way way way more money is stolen through screwed up bank transfers and legacy systems than is through ethereum.

I agree that if a design is flawed, it should be fixed. As Sam said, this particular function isn't even part of the erc20 spec though. So a flag during an audit would help, sure, but I don't think someone who blindly clicks "approve" is doing so after reading an audit anyway.

Ultimately people have to try their very best to be stewards of their money. If you're sitting on $25m in one wallet, it's likely you can afford someone to help you before you click buttons, or can get time to educate yourself on basic security practices.

I don't want to blame a victim of course, but I don't think everything here is the fault of the "design" either ya know? There are many pieces to this: underlying design, poor education, bad ux, malicious actors who think they can steal money without repercussions.
It's true, we can't "save" everyone. But we can give tools and guidance for those who have a long-term vision.
I focus on the very last one as some of you know. Others focus on other ones. Together this will get better, but for now I'm as disappointed as you are at the amount of money stolen.

Fot the better token design, Lukso (coincidentally co-founded by Fabian Vogelsteller, who also approved original ERC-20 spec) is doing great work https://docs.lukso.tech/standards/nft-2.0/introduction - Lukso is EVM chain

Notable websites lacking the required protection and thus vulnerable right now, include:

● gmail.com – plaintext passwords stored in HTML source code

● cloudflare.com – plaintext passwords in HTML source code

● facebook.com – user inputs can be extracted via the DOM API

● citibank.com – user inputs can be extracted via the DOM API

● irs.gov – SSNs are visible in plaintext form on the web page source code

● capitalone.com – SSNs are visible in plaintext form on the web page source code

● usenix.org – SSNs are visible in plaintext form on the web page source code

● amazon.com – credit card details (including security code) and ZIP code are visible in plaintext form on the page's source code

Is there any reason people haven’t gone with a time based approve lock? 

From what I understand, the real way that an approve call us vulnerable is if someone consumes an approval when they detect their allowance being set to another value.

You can implement a per-spender time threshold that tracks when the approval was used last and allow it to be mutated after f.e. one hour and fail otherwise IF the new approval is greater than the last.
My guess is simplicity and gas savings. EIP2612 permits are time-bound though so that feature exists kind of, just not in ERC20.
Phishing approvals are immediately consumed, so time lock won't help

disable reentrancy by default (as Stylus did) on the compiler level and following a design like the ERC677 draft (https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/677) does seem like a route worth considering imo.
What is the exact issue you have with approve then? How would phishing a transfer call differ from phishing an approve call?
officercia.mirror.xyz/Y3xDO0XlAvIzJBwNhFZnvPWLiztWxIp1KHqg-B0kKxI
This seems like a permit rather than approve resource.
Because users know what transfer is, they won't do it. Here is the long version https://vxtwitter.com/moo9000/status/1619319039230197760
People are not getting scammed with transfer(), or it is very rare.

I’d say approve is integral to DeFi interoperability and seems like the lesser evil of most solutions devised to date. 

What you describe is mostly an ecosystem awareness / wallet UX issue rather than a flaw in the approve function itself.
Ok I propose a more radical solution, native support 😃 `msg.asset`
Sorry, but this is kind of non-holistic thinking that is among security researchers and what I hate. You fail to see the bigger picture and just focus on your own desk.
what exactly is the bigger picture here?
we should all use lukso?
No, we should agree that ERC-20 is a problem and work together for the replacement.
Of course if you think ERC-20 is the god's will and there cannot be anything better, it is never going to happen. A common thought among people here.
It all comes down to human arrogance
i just think its kind of ridiculous to try and replace a standard so entrenched in the entire ecosystem that evm forks literally name their things "brc20" and "trc20"
like, can we please start with something anchored in reality first
You lack ambition
a video player was commonly called a VHS not that long ago, doesnt mean we should have stuck to that standard forever...
When there is will, there is hope

You are assuming people haven’t thought of alternatives. They have, multiple. Approve stems from the need for smart contracts to transfer assets from EOAs. 

The only way to do so is:

- a direct transfer
- a way for the token to know the smart contract is authorised to transfer 

I do not see any alternative. Direct transfers that inform the recipient introduce reentrancy attacks (i.e. ERC677) whilst authorisations either use signatures (can be scammed) or transactions that authorise (can be scammed).

Even if you used more naive approaches such as tx.origin validation it would still be possible to scam it and even more dangerous arguably.
Developers understand, but it’s not user friendly
You approach this from an EIP perspective, you have to approach this from a logical perspective to understand. It’s either a direct transfer or an approval to the party to transfer on our behalf.

It’s an EVM issue, not a code issue.
@pcaversaccio agrees with you here
so basically its the evm equivalent of `transfer()` and `transferAndCall()`?

The problem with transferAndCall() is still that you can only interact with one token at once. It's rare, but for example some swaps take two tokens as input. However this is such a borderline case that it can have it's own special smart contract path and does not need to be exposed to the user.

Also for the proposed solutions or partial solutions over the years include
- Re-entrancy locks by default to avoid this attack vector (Hello Vyper)
- Various transferAndCall() schemes (they kind of work, but we never agreed on the standard)
- Message signing schemes that make building transfers complicated for the wallets and users (permit(), Permit2, EIP-3009)
- Having native assets on EVM besides ETH (even I believe this is too much and will never happen)

Note that some tokens do implement transferAndCall() and have been more or less successful it, though I am undecided whether we should settle here or not.

Yes, non-EVM is the keyword. The EVM supports re-entrancies by default and I doubt this is going to change as it is a core feature of how DeFi interoperability occurs.

I also am not sure how `transferAndCall` would work for custodial contracts. How do you validate how many funds were transferred in that exact call? 

You cannot measure your balance before and after, so you will blindly trust the input arguments of your function? Do you create a dedicated non-custodial router for every single interaction your system makes and disable direct calls?

Due to how the EIP-20 functions, the `transferFrom` pattern guarantees that you will get the assets you are transferring whereas the `transferAndCall` part would require additional validation on the recipient end.

I sincerely do not understand why it is preferable to introduce intricately complex and migraine-inducing code workarounds or even chain-wide EIP upgrades instead of educating the users of the ecosystem. 

Private key management is a nightmare by itself and there are no code workarounds, users of the crypto space by definition need to receive domain-specific education regardless. 

Adding one more paragraph or even two sentences to the existing "do not sign transfer transactions" statement does not seem like the end of the world for me and this does not stem from "ignorance" but rather from how the real world works.
Because we are never going to get any mainstream adoption if we need to educate the users. Things must be simple and scam free.
